## Dune's Environmental and Climate Themes

Frank Herbert's 1965 novel Dune is widely considered one of the best sci-fi books ever written and one of the first to take environmental concerns seriously. In addition to changing the science fiction genre, Herbert's novel became a touchstone for the burgeoning environmental movement of the late 1960s and 70s.(no content)Some scholars have argued that Dune is one of the earliest examples of climate fiction, a story intimately concerned with exploring the relationships and interactions between organisms and their environment.(no content)While the genre of climate fiction was popularized in the 2010s in response to real global climate change, Dune as well as other early science fiction works have retroactively been considered pioneering examples of the genre.

## Environmental Allegories and Real-World Parallels

Critics view spice as an analogy for oil and the oil trade. The Dune series can "be construed as a thinly veiled allegory of our world's insatiable appetite for oil and other petroleum products."(no content)Readers in the 1960s understood Dune as a thinly veiled metaphor for the global demand for oil, an interpretation strengthened by Herbert's arguably problematic use of Middle Eastern culture and language within the story.(no content)The novel examines what happens when humans try to bend nature to their will and, as Herbert wrote in his dedication, predicts the ramifications of abusing a land for its resources.

## Climate Change Discussion in Film Adaptations

During a press conference following the release of the first part of Dune, Villeneuve connected his film to climate change, saying that the book is "a prediction of what will happen" in the 21st century and about "survival." However, both film adaptations downplay the novel's environmental message and treat the book's ecological themes as extraneous rather than central, despite readers and book critics immediately pegging Dune as a prescient environmental text.
